channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Friends of Elon Musk who disliked Twitter’s direction—including “PayPal mafia”—secretly pushed him to launch a bid for the platform https://t.co/g7FWc9hhe9

From @WSJopinion: Putin really may break the nuclear taboo. It seems unthinkable, but American leaders’ failure to think about it heightens the risk it will happen, writes @Peggynoonannyc https://t.co/47xJJThKVz

Javelin missiles and other weapons supplied by the U.S. and Western allies play a critical role in enabling Ukraine to repel Russia’s onslaught. The bottleneck for this influx of aid is training. “You need to behave like snipers. Play spy games.” https://t.co/ahOo6nnnfH

Airbnb is telling employees they can now work from almost anywhere in the world without a pay cut in a move that could entice other companies to follow suit and bolster the company’s business https://t.co/sToJXOzfUB
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/9vBe3tO0wN
The FBI conducted potentially millions of searches of Americans’ electronic data last year without a warrant, a U.S. intelligence report said https://t.co/cNmrSoHJkM
Poland has donated at least 240 Soviet-style tanks to Ukraine as allies race to help Ukraine rebuff Russia’s advance in the east of the country https://t.co/F2xvwlSiil
Elon Musk has sold roughly $8.5 billion worth of Tesla stock in the three days after agreeing to buy Twitter for $44 billion, according to regulatory filings https://t.co/phzBbs5R2S

After a record number of people bought guns during the pandemic, some cities are reporting more firearms are being stolen and used in murders, including the recent mass shooting in Sacramento https://t.co/8qlEg8OFyG

Breaking: Los Angeles Dodgers part-owner Todd Boehly is set to enter exclusive talks in the bidding war to acquire Chelsea FC from Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, people familiar with the matter say https://t.co/7Do1pdO4uq

Airbnb is telling employees they can now work from almost anywhere in the world without a pay cut in a move that could entice other companies to follow suit and bolster the company’s business https://t.co/PvZLdOWWWx
Without foreign middlemen, Russia will struggle to find buyers for its oil, the foundation of the country’s economic wealth https://t.co/PQ9MBziF2o

Elon Musk sold roughly $4 billion worth of Tesla stock after agreeing to buy Twitter, as he looks for cash to finance his takeover of the social-media company #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/3HC40QOOdw https://t.co/KJY6mUSek3

Javelin missiles and other weapons supplied by the U.S. and Western allies play a critical role in enabling Ukrainian forces to repel Russia’s massive onslaught; a bottleneck is training https://t.co/UfYVsqf2mu

Russian forces have riddled Ukrainian fields with mines and destroyed equipment, in what farmers and Kyiv say is a deliberate effort to hurt Ukraine’s globally important agricultural industry https://t.co/gvjE0Y6Sqv

Elon Musk has sold roughly $4 billion worth of Tesla stock in the two days after agreeing to buy Twitter for $44 billion, according to regulatory filings made public late Thursday https://t.co/yfQne2ajOW
Amazon posted its first quarterly loss since 2015, hurt by slower sales growth and its stake in electric-vehicle maker Rivian https://t.co/548FYyuM0V
Apple posted one of its best quarters in its 46-year history as iPhone sales exceeded expectations https://t.co/u9vZmsGvUM
Corn and soybeans prices have risen nearly to records, signaling higher food inflation to come https://t.co/QLHy1ttV4g

Elon Musk reported selling a total of more than 4.4 million Tesla shares on Tuesday and Wednesday at prices between about $870 and $1,000 a share, filings show. “No further TSLA sales planned after today," Musk tweeted Thursday. https://t.co/iDZbAuoidR
With foreign exporters pulling out, Russia will struggle to find buyers for its oil, the foundation of the country's economic wealth https://t.co/cO7Ago4yef
A person in Colorado has tested positive for a version of avian influenza, the first known human case in the U.S. of a bird flu that has ravaged poultry flocks https://t.co/z2VDcENqdT

Airbnb is telling employees they can now work from almost anywhere in the world without a pay cut, in a move that could entice other companies to follow suit and bolster the company’s business https://t.co/SFTFHmeX6v

Elon Musk has sold roughly $4 billion worth of Tesla stock in the two days after agreeing to buy Twitter for $44 billion, according to regulatory filings made public late Thursday https://t.co/2giCrwuuJH
The Justice Department has sued Paul Manafort for nearly $3 million in tax-related penalties, reviving allegations from Robert Mueller’s Russia investigation https://t.co/8N4t93d8kq
From @WSJopinion: Unless the U.S. prepares to win a nuclear war, it risks losing one, writes Seth Cropsey https://t.co/wGcKPqj3a3

Tesla previously warned investors that its CEO might need to sell stock to cover loans. Now, for his Twitter deal, Elon Musk is borrowing more against his stake in the car company. https://t.co/h6epWWgs3w
A national ban on menthol cigarettes moved a step closer after the FDA published a plan to prohibit their sale. It wouldn't take effect until at least 2024. https://t.co/5SGlgPGhU0
The White House will ask Congress for an additional $33 billion in military, economic and humanitarian aid for Ukraine https://t.co/SQ6tAaD3qp
Germany is now ready to stop buying Russian oil, clearing the way for a European Union ban on crude imports from Russia, government officials said https://t.co/FuBDc0hYSL
From @WSJopinion: Elon Musk can fix Twitter culture, writes Holman Jenkins. Its new owner might tap Google for ideas on detoxifying a politicized workplace. https://t.co/Fcf4qLW5Nc
A 200-foot-long wildlife overpass under construction in Los Angeles aims to help the long-term survival of mountain lions and other animals https://t.co/NvrzlBIAMU

Russian forces have riddled Ukrainian fields with mines and destroyed equipment, in what farmers and Kyiv say is a deliberate effort to hurt Ukraine’s globally important agricultural industry https://t.co/T1eOGASlKw
The U.S. economy shrank at a 1.4% annual rate in the first quarter, its first contraction since early in the pandemic https://t.co/DEuYrJyCaa
Ukraine filed its first war-crime charges against Russian soldiers, accusing 10 of taking civilians hostage and mistreating them in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha https://t.co/ZPwaLmZxWk
Palm oil is one of the world’s most ubiquitous food commodities, found in candy bars, ice cream, pizza dough and cooking oil. It is about to get harder to source. https://t.co/dsJKbnyfIt
Elon Musk broke nearly every rule in the deal-making playbook. How he landed Twitter anyway. https://t.co/6IoVe0LAWh
Twitter will take on significant amounts of debt as part of its deal to go private, exposing the company to rising interest rates https://t.co/kW9tUx6Qx0
Elon Musk targeted Twitter’s legal boss on the platform two days after his takeover bid was approved, drawing employee backlash https://t.co/guaz4jp3HZ
Jacob and Jordan Kingsley took their 11-month-old son Shepherd to his first Cincinnati Reds game. They left with a foul ball and a viral moment. https://t.co/uAl20WBa9G

ESPN anchor Sage Steele is suing the network, alleging the company retaliated against her for comments she made in a podcast interview, breaching her contract and violating her free-speech rights https://t.co/itdUqTFpMS
FreeWire, a developer of electric-vehicle chargers, has gained $125 million in new financing from BlackRock and others https://t.co/qSEdUdQkbk

From @WSJopinion: Ukraine doesn’t have the weapons or stockpiles of munitions for the slugfest that has begun. The U.S. and NATO must urgently provide $40 billion in military aid, not $4 billion, writes @BingWest https://t.co/0BrFoOT8F3

A judge has ruled that Elon Musk didn’t act unlawfully when Tesla took over SolarCity. A group of shareholders had alleged that Musk controlled the takeover while having a financial interest in both companies. https://t.co/00E9YawG9S

New official figures published by Moscow showed the country’s economy suffered a modest hit from sanctions during the first weeks of the country’s war on Ukraine, in contrast to independent surveys that recorded a sharp decline in activity https://t.co/bLwmZYaNIM

From @WSJopinion: “Successful business moguls like Elon Musk are a fruit of U.S. culture, not symptoms of its rot. The ability to build and succeed is an inseparable part of the American Dream,” writes Nathan Biller, a student at Colgate University. https://t.co/UnzcFgFYRR
The Trumps’ Washington hotel sale is poised to close next week, with an investment fund paying $375 million and beginning the process of rebranding it as a Waldorf Astoria https://t.co/qRrpAb04Ma
Trevor Reed, a U.S. citizen and former Marine, who has been detained in Russia since 2019, was released in a prisoner swap https://t.co/m18DIhtiD4
A Myanmar court sentenced ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi to five years in prison, the third verdict in a raft of cases brought against her by the country’s military junta https://t.co/0OxJEVG3ve

An ammunition depot caught fire near Russia’s border with Ukraine, a local official said, the latest in a series of incidents to afflict Russian military facilities in regions adjacent to Ukraine in recent weeks https://t.co/Y6U9StmgmQ
